questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with dilated tortuous veins in the leg. He had a history of trauma 10 years back in the same limb. On examination, the dilated tortuous vein showed pulsatility. Most likely diagnosis in this patient will be? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AV fistula

 

An arteriovenous (AV) fistula is an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein. The history of trauma in the same limb suggests a possible traumatic AV fistula. The presence of pulsatility in the veins is a key indicator, as it implies that arterial pressure is being transmitted to the veins. This is not typical for varicose veins, aneurysms, or hemangiomas, making AV fistula the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicose vein: Varicose veins are typically dilated, tortuous veins caused by incompetent valves but do not show pulsatility.

 

Option B. Aneurysm: Aneurysms involve arterial dilation and do not present with pulsatile veins.

 

Option C. Hemangioma: Hemangiomas are benign tumors of blood vessels, usually presenting as a mass and not associated with pulsatile veins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A history of trauma with the presence of dilated tortuous veins showing pulsatility strongly indicates an arteriovenous fistula due to the transmission of arterial pulsation to the veins

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a 6-year-old male who presents with a midline neck swelling that moves upward with the protrusion of the tongue?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sistrunk operation

 

The 6-year-old male presents with a midline neck swelling that moves upward with the protrusion of the tongue, which is characteristic of a thyroglossal duct cyst. This cyst forms from remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which usually obliterates as the thyroid gland descends from the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue to its final position in the neck. When part of this duct remains patent, it can form a cyst.

 

The appropriate treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst is the Sistrunk operation. This surgical procedure involves removing the cyst along with the central portion of the hyoid bone and a tract leading to the base of the tongue to ensure complete excision and reduce the risk of recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemithyroidectomy: This is incorrect as it involves removing one lobe of the thyroid gland, which is not necessary for treating a thyroglossal duct cyst.

 

Option C. Total thyroidectomy: This is incorrect because removing the entire thyroid gland is not indicated for a thyroglossal duct cyst.

 

Option D. Subtotal thyroidectomy: This is incorrect as it involves partial removal of the thyroid gland, which is also not indicated for a thyroglossal duct cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sistrunk operation is the treatment of choice for a thyroglossal duct cyst, involving the removal of the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid bone, and the tract to the base of the tongue.

questions.text: A 27-year-old lady presented to OPD with a complaint of pain and redness in her breast with fever. On clinical examination, a 5 x 4 cm area of redness was noted in the breast with ipsilateral axillary lymph node enlargement. What should be the preferred management in this lady? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antibiotics and breast support

 

The clinical presentation of pain, redness, fever, and a 5 x 4 cm area of redness with axillary lymph node enlargement is indicative of mastitis. Mastitis is an inflammation of the breast tissue that is often associated with infection. It is common in breastfeeding women but can also occur in non-lactating women. The typical management for mastitis includes antibiotics to treat the infection and breast support to reduce discomfort.

 

  • Antibiotics: These are essential to treat the bacterial infection causing the mastitis.
  • Breast support: Proper support can help relieve pain and reduce swelling.

 

If there were additional signs such as swelling, fluctuation, high-grade fever with chills, or ultrasound findings showing fluid collection, the diagnosis could be an abscess, which would require a different treatment approach involving aspiration or drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mammography: This is not a first-line investigation or treatment for mastitis. Mammography is typically used for screening and diagnostic purposes in breast cancer and other breast pathologies.

 

Option B. Incision and drainage: This is the treatment for a breast abscess, not uncomplicated mastitis. There is no indication of abscess formation in the given scenario.

 

Option C. Hot compresses and conservative treatment: While hot compresses can provide some symptomatic relief, they are not a substitute for antibiotics in the treatment of an infection like mastitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for mastitis includes antibiotics to address the infection and breast support to alleviate discomfort. Recognize the symptoms of mastitis and differentiate it from a breast abscess, which requires a different management approach.

questions.text: John, a 55-year-old man, visits his primary care physician due to progressively worsening symptoms of difficulty swallowing and chest pain over the past few weeks. The physician refers John for an esophageal endoscopy to investigate the cause of his symptoms. During the endoscopy, the gastroenterologist observes serpiginous ulcers in John's esophagus. What is the likely diagnosis indicated by these findings?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. CMV esophagitis

 

Explanation:

 

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) esophagitis is an infection of the esophagus caused by the Cytomegalovirus. It predominantly affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS or transplant recipients. The characteristic endoscopic finding in CMV esophagitis is the presence of large, linear or serpiginous (snake-like) ulcers, often located in the distal esophagus. These ulcers typically have well-defined edges and are surrounded by relatively normal mucosa, which helps to differentiate them from other types of esophagitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida Esophagitis: Candida esophagitis is a fungal infection caused by Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans. It is common in immunocompromised patients or those on prolonged antibiotics or inhaled steroids. Endoscopic findings typically show white-yellow plaques or patches that can be scraped off, often described as having a "cottage cheese-like" appearance, rather than serpiginous ulcers.

 

Option C. Herpetic Esophagitis: Herpetic esophagitis is caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) and can affect both immunocompromised and immunocompetent individuals. It is characterized by odynophagia (painful swallowing) and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing). Endoscopically, herpetic esophagitis usually presents with small, well-circumscribed ulcers that resemble "volcano-like" or "punched-out" lesions, which are different from the serpiginous ulcers seen in CMV esophagitis.

 

Option D. Radiation Esophagitis: Radiation esophagitis is a side effect of radiation therapy, particularly for cancers in the chest area, such as lung cancer. It manifests with symptoms like pain, difficulty swallowing, and a sensation of something stuck in the throat. Endoscopic findings may include mucosal redness, swelling, and non-specific ulcerations, but not the distinct serpiginous ulcers typical of CMV esophagitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serpiginous ulcers in the esophagus observed during endoscopy are characteristic of CMV esophagitis, especially in immunocompromised patients. This feature helps differentiate it from other forms of esophagitis such as Candida, herpetic, and radiation-induced esophagitis.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with flame burns. On clinical evaluation, there were deep burns involving the left upper limb, the right upper limb, and the anterior aspect of the chest and abdomen. How much percentage of burns would it be classified as? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36%

 

The Rule of Nines, also known as Wallace's rule, is used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns in adults. This method divides the body into sections, each accounting for approximately 9% (or multiples thereof) of the TBSA.

 

  • Left upper limb: Each upper limb is considered to account for 9% of the TBSA.
  • Right upper limb: Similarly, the right upper limb accounts for another 9%.
  • Anterior aspect of chest and abdomen: The anterior trunk, which includes the chest and abdomen, is considered to be 18% of the TBSA.

 

To calculate the total percentage of burns:

 

  • Left upper limb: 9%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Anterior chest and abdomen: 18%

 

Adding these together: 9%+9%+18%=36%

 

Thus, the patient has burns covering 36% of their body surface area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total body surface area (TBSA) involved is usually worked out by the Wallace Rule of Nines wherein each upper limb is 9% of TBSA, 9% each for the front and back of lower limb, 9% for the front and back of chest, 9% for the front and back of abdomen, the head and neck 9% and 1% for the perineum.

questions.text: A morbidly obese patient underwent cholecystectomy and subsequently complained of pain in the legs after walking for some distance. Which investigation would be most appropriate for further evaluation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duplex scan 

 

The patient's symptoms suggest occurrence of post operative Deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The investigations listed are used to evaluate vascular conditions:

 

This ultrasound-based diagnostic technique combines traditional ultrasound to visualize the structure of the blood vessels and Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow within the vessels. It is the first-line investigation for DVT as it is non-invasive, widely available, and cost-effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a type of MRI that visualizes blood vessels. It is a good non-invasive option to visualize blood flow and vascular anatomy but is less commonly used as a first-line test due to cost and availability.

 

Option C. CT angiography: This imaging modality uses computed tomography (CT) combined with a contrast agent to visualize vascular structures. It's useful in detailed mapping of blood vessels but exposes the patient to radiation and contrast, which may not be suitable for all patients.

 

Option D. USG: Ultrasound (USG) is useful for various diagnostic purposes but on its own may not be sufficient for a full vascular assessment in the case of DVT unless it's part of a duplex scan.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For a morbidly obese patient presenting with leg pain consistent with DVT post-cholecystectomy, a duplex scan is the most appropriate initial investigation to evaluate for DVT.

questions.text: Heller's operation is done for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Achalasia cardia

 

Heller's operation, also known as Heller myotomy, is a surgical procedure designed to treat achalasia. During this procedure, the surgeon makes a series of cuts into the thickened muscle of the LES to allow it to relax and improve the passage of food into the stomach. So, Heller's operation is indeed done for achalasia cardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma esophagus: Carcinoma of the esophagus refers to cancer that starts in the esophagus. While surgeries are often performed for esophageal cancer, Heller's operation specifically is not one of them. Instead, procedures like esophagectomy (removal of all or part of the esophagus) are performed for esophageal cancer.

 

Option C. Esophageal stricture: An esophageal stricture is a narrowing of the esophagus, which can lead to difficulty swallowing. It can result from various causes, including acid reflux or injuries to the esophagus. Esophageal dilatation (stretching of the esophagus using dilators) is commonly done for esophageal strictures.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a condition in infants where the muscle at the junction between the stomach and the small intestine (the pylorus) becomes enlarged, leading to obstruction. The treatment for this condition is a surgery called pyloromyotomy, where the thickened muscle is split to relieve the obstruction.

 

In conclusion, among the given options, Heller's operation is specifically done for achalasia cardia (Option A).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heller's myotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat achalasia cardia by cutting the lower esophageal sphincter muscle to relieve obstruction and improve swallowing.

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is cosmetically preferred for appendectomy? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lanz

 

The Lanz incision is the most cosmetically preferred incision for an appendectomy. It is made along the skin crease, resulting in a less noticeable scar.

 

Gridiron or McBurney incisions are muscle-splitting incisions centered at McBurney's point. They are traditional incisions used for appendectomy but may result in more visible scars compared to the Lanz incision.

 

Rutherford Morrison incision is a muscle-cutting incision that provides adequate exposure during appendectomy, especially for more complicated cases. However, it is less cosmetically appealing due to the larger scar it leaves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gridiron: This incision is centered at McBurney's point and involves splitting the muscles, which can leave a more noticeable scar.

 

Option B. Rutherford Morrison: This is a muscle-cutting incision that provides good exposure for appendectomy but results in a larger, less cosmetic scar.

 

Option D. McBurney: Similar to the Gridiron incision, it is centered at McBurney's point and involves splitting the muscles, leading to a more visible scar compared to the Lanz incision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lanz incision is cosmetically preferred for appendectomy due to its alignment along the skin crease, resulting in a less noticeable scar compared to other traditional incisions.

questions.text: A patient suffering from leprosy develops a dirty wound on his foot. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Debride and dressing

 

The image shows a lower limb ulcer in a patient with a history of leprosy. This type of ulcer is typically neuropathic or trophic due to nerve damage caused by leprosy, leading to decreased sensation and subsequent injury. The first and most crucial step in managing such ulcers is debridement and proper dressing. Debridement removes necrotic tissue, slough, and any other debris, which promotes a clean wound environment conducive to healing. Proper dressing keeps the ulcer protected and aids in healing by maintaining an optimal moisture balance.

 

Subsequent steps after debridement include appropriate foot care, offloading pressure from the affected area, and limb rehabilitation to prevent recurrence. However, the immediate next step is to clean the wound, making debridement and dressing the correct initial intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start MDT: Multi-drug therapy (MDT) is the treatment for leprosy to address the underlying infection but does not directly contribute to the healing of an existing ulcer. While MDT is crucial for treating leprosy, it does not manage the wound directly and should not be the first step in ulcer management.

 

Option C. Foot care, limb rehabilitation: Foot care and rehabilitation are essential components of managing neuropathic ulcers, especially in preventing further injuries and recurrences. However, these measures alone will not heal an existing dirty or necrotic ulcer. The ulcer must be cleaned and dressed first before these steps can be effective.

 

Option D. Deformity correction: This will help in healing of ulcer at a later stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of a neuropathic or trophic ulcer in a leprosy patient, the first step should be debridement and dressing to clean the wound. This is followed by comprehensive foot care and rehabilitation to support healing and prevent recurrence.

choices.text: Needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space
Tube thoracostomy in the 4th intercostal space

questions.text: Adult male, following a road traffic accident, was brought to the emergency with respiratory distress. On clinical evaluation, breath sounds were absent on one side and subcutaneous emphysema was noted. Vitals were unstable. Chest X-ray showed the following. Next step in the management of this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space

 

The patient presents with signs and symptoms indicative of a tension pneumothorax, a medical emergency. Tension pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased pressure on the affected side, which compresses the lung and shifts the mediastinum to the opposite side.

 

Key signs of tension pneumothorax include:

 

  • Respiratory distress
  • Absent breath sounds on one side
  • Subcutaneous emphysema
  • Unstable vitals
  • Mediastinal shift visible on the chest X-ray

 

Immediate Management: The first step in managing a tension pneumothorax is needle decompression to quickly relieve the pressure. This procedure is typically performed in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line, not the 5th intercostal space as mentioned in the answer. However, for the context of the given options, we will proceed with needle decompression as the primary action.

 

Subsequent Management: Following needle decompression, Intercostal Drain (ICD) should be performed to ensure continued evacuation of air and prevent recurrence. This is usually done in the "triangle of safety." This the best management in this type of condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tube thoracostomy in the 4th intercostal space: While a tube thoracostomy is a necessary step following initial needle decompression, it is not the immediate next step in the acute management of tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: This procedure is indicated if there is a direct airway injury or if the patient is unable to maintain their airway. In the case of tension pneumothorax, the primary issue is with ventilation, not the airway itself.

 

Option D. Tracheostomy: Tracheostomy is not indicated in the acute management of tension pneumothorax. It is generally reserved for long-term airway management in cases of chronic conditions or when prolonged intubation is anticipated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate management of a tension pneumothorax involves needle decompression to rapidly relieve intrapleural pressure, followed by tube thoracostomy for definitive management. Proper identification and prompt intervention are crucial to prevent severe complications or death.

questions.text: Identify the stapler in the image given below: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Linear stapler

 

The above instrument is a linear stapler.

 

Use: It is used to close the bowel completely or partially.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A linear stapler is used to close the bowel completely or partially, providing a secure and uniform closure in gastrointestinal surgeries.

choices.text: Superficial from border with normal tissue

questions.text: A patient presents with a growth on the lip as shown. How is the biopsy taken? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superficial from border with normal tissue

 

In cases of ulcerative growths, such as squamous cell carcinoma of the lip, the biopsy is typically taken from the border of the ulcer where the tissue is actively proliferating. This method is known as a wedge or edge biopsy, where a small section from the edge of the ulcer and adjacent normal tissue is removed. This approach is preferred because the most diagnostically significant tissue lies at the proliferating margins of the ulcer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incisional: An incisional biopsy involves removing a piece of tissue from the core of the lesion. This technique is typically used for solid masses, such as breast lumps, where a core sample is required to assess the deeper tissue architecture. It is not appropriate for ulcerative lesions where the proliferative activity is at the edges.

 

Option B. Excisional: An excisional biopsy involves removing the entire lesion along with some surrounding normal tissue. While this is useful for small lesions where complete removal is feasible, it is not the standard initial approach for large or ulcerated lesions like those seen in aggressive lip cancers.

 

Option D. Deep biopsy: A deep biopsy targets deeper tissue layers, which may be necessary for certain internal masses but is not suitable for superficial ulcerative lesions like lip growths, where the pathology is best captured at the surface and edges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For ulcerative lesions, particularly squamous cell carcinomas, a biopsy should be taken from the border or edge of the lesion, including some normal tissue, as this area contains the most diagnostically relevant proliferating cells.

questions.text: Which type of thyroid carcinoma has the least likelihood of lymph node metastasis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid

 

Explanation: 

 

Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid has the least likelihood of lymph node metastasis among the given options. Follicular carcinoma typically presents as a solitary thyroid nodule with a strong tendency for hematogenous spread rather than lymphatic spread. While it commonly metastasizes to bones (particularly thoracic vertebrae and skull) via blood vessels, lymph node involvement is rare, except in the Hurthle cell variant which may show lymph node metastases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid - Incorrect because papillary carcinoma has a high propensity for lymph node metastasis. It frequently spreads to Level VI (central compartment) lymph nodes, and lymph node involvement is often present even in early disease. In fact, enlarged cervical lymph nodes may be the presenting feature of papillary carcinoma in some cases.

 

Option B. Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid - Incorrect because medullary carcinoma frequently metastasizes to lymph nodes. Involvement of lymph nodes occurs in 50-60% of cases of medullary carcinoma. This tumor, which arises from parafollicular C cells, also commonly spreads hematogenously, with the liver being the most common site of distant metastasis.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid - Incorrect because anaplastic carcinoma is characterized by rapid growth, extensive local invasion, and early lymph node metastasis. Being the most aggressive thyroid malignancy, it shows infiltration of surrounding structures including lymph nodes early in its course, along with distant metastases typically to the lungs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid primarily spreads hematogenously to bones rather than via lymphatics, making it unique among thyroid carcinomas in having a relatively low rate of lymph node metastasis.

questions.text: The sequence of color change in Raynaudâ€™s disease: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) White - Blue - Red

 

Explanation:

 

Raynaud's disease follows a characteristic sequence of color changes in the digits. The phenomenon shows a typical pattern: first, the digits turn white (pallor/syncope) due to arteriolar constriction; then they become blue/cyanotic (asphyxia) as capillaries dilate and fill with deoxygenated blood; finally, they turn red (reactive hyperemia) when arterioles relax and oxygenated blood returns to the dilated capillaries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Red - Blue - White This sequence is incorrect. The initial phase of Raynaud's is vasoconstriction causing pallor (white), not redness. The arterial supply is initially shut down, not increased.

 

Option C. White - Red - Blue This sequence is incorrect. After the initial white phase, blood stagnates in the capillaries leading to cyanosis (blue), not redness. Red is the final recovery phase.

 

Option D. Red - White - Blue This is the complete reverse of the correct sequence and physiologically impossible in Raynaud's disease. The condition begins with vasoconstriction (white), not vasodilation (red).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Raynaud's disease manifests with a pathognomonic triple-color change sequence (white-blue-red) corresponding to the pathophysiological stages of vasospasm: initial vasoconstriction (pallor), followed by capillary dilatation with deoxygenated blood (cyanosis), and finally arteriolar relaxation with return of oxygenated blood (erythema).

questions.text: A patient has undergone cholecystectomy few days back and now the patient has presented with upper Abdominal pain. MRCP was done which showed leak of bile from the cystic duct stump. Pt is hemodynamically stable which of the following should be the next line of management? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ERCP and stenting

 

The correct option is Option B. ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) and stenting

 

ERCP is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used primarily to diagnose and treat conditions of the bile and pancreatic ducts. In the context of a known bile leak, as revealed by the MRCP, ERCP can be employed both to visualize the site of the leak and to deploy a stent. This stent can bridge the gap where the leak is, allowing the bile to flow normally into the intestine and simultaneously giving the leaky site a chance to heal. This makes it a less invasive option than surgical intervention for managing bile leaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): This is a diagnostic imaging tool. A CECT provides detailed imaging of internal structures and can help in diagnosing a variety of conditions. However, in the context of the given scenario where the patient has had an MRCP that already shows a bile leak, a further CECT might not provide additional useful information for direct management.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: While it can be used to directly visualize and repair a bile leak, it's a major surgical procedure with potential complications. It's generally considered when other less invasive options are not viable or have failed.

 

Option D. Conservative treatment with antibiotics: While antibiotics can help to prevent or treat infections, they won't directly address a bile leak. Hence, relying solely on antibiotics wouldn't solve the main problem. However, antibiotics might be used in conjunction with other treatments if there's a concern about bile-related infection or sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a hemodynamically stable patient with a bile leak post-cholecystectomy, as shown by MRCP, the next line of management is ERCP and stenting to bridge the leak and allow healing.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the superficial parotid gland on FNAC? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial parotidectomy

 

The preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the parotid gland, as confirmed by fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC), is:

 

This is the treatment of choice for a benign parotid tumors like pleomorphic adenoma. It involves the surgical removal of the entire superficial lobe. Enucleation or simple excision is avoided as the tumor has projections (pseudopodia) which may be left behind leading to recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide local incision: This is not typically performed for benign parotid tumors. However, now a days it is becoming an alternate to superficial parotidectomy.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy: This is not a standard treatment for benign parotid tumors as they are typically not responsive to chemotherapy agents.

 

Option D. Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is not a standard treatment for benign parotid tumors as it is generally reserved for cancer treatment and not indicated for benign conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Superficial parotidectomy is the preferred treatment for a benign tumors like pleomorphic adenoma, providing targeted removal of the entire superficial lobe.

questions.text: During the assessment of the breathing component of a trauma patient, which of the following is the most life-threatening injury that should be identified and managed immediately? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension pneumothorax

 

Injuries that significantly impair ventilation in the short term, such as tension pneumothorax, must be identified during the primary survey and treated immediately.

 

It is important to note that the ABCDE protocol of trauma care should be followed, with the primary survey focusing on identifying and managing life-threatening injuries, followed by the secondary survey to identify all other injuries

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, causing it to collapse. This can lead to a rapid buildup of pressure in the chest cavity, compressing the heart and great vessels, which can be life-threatening. It is crucial to identify and manage tension pneumothorax promptly by performing a needle decompression to release the trapped air.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical spine injury: While cervical spine injuries can be serious and require prompt attention, they are not primarily related to the respiratory system. They can result in neurological deficits but are not immediately life-threatening in terms of breathing.

 

Option C. Blunt cardiac injury: Blunt cardiac injury can result from chest trauma and may affect the heart's function. While it can be serious, it may not immediately impact the patient's ability to breathe. However, it requires evaluation and management.

 

Option D. Flail chest: Flail chest is no longer considered an immediate threat to life as per ATLS 2018 guidelines.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest sign in Crohn's disease? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aphthous ulcers

 

These are shallow, round ulcers that are often seen in the mouth but can also occur in the small intestine and colon in Crohn's disease. They are the earliest sign of Crohn's disease and are often recurrent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobblestone appearance: This is a characteristic finding in Crohn's disease and refers to the appearance of the mucosa with raised, rounded, and separated areas resembling cobblestones. This is caused by transmural inflammation and can be seen in the terminal ileum and colon.

 

Option B. Deep fissured ulcers: These are another feature of Crohn's disease that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract. They are deep, often extend into the submucosa, and can lead to the formation of fistulas or abscesses.

 

Option C. Rose-thorn appearance: This term is sometimes used to describe the appearance of the mucosa in Crohn's disease, where there are linear ulcers that are surrounded by raised, edematous tissue. This pattern is more commonly seen in the colon.

 

Educational Objective:


Aphthous ulcers are the earliest sign of Crohn's disease, often appearing in the mouth and gastrointestinal tract before more severe lesions develop.

choices.text: Urethral repair with buccal mucosal graft

questions.text: Patient presents with acute urinary retention, and suprapubic catheterization is done. Urethrogram show a long segment stricture. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urethral repair with buccal mucosal graft

 

For long urethral strictures, typically those greater than 1-2 cm in length, the preferred management is urethral repair using a buccal mucosal graft. This surgical approach involves using a graft from the buccal mucosa (inner cheek lining) to replace or augment the narrowed segment of the urethra, thereby restoring normal urine flow. Buccal mucosal grafts are favored due to their durability, excellent tissue characteristics, and high success rates in reconstructive urology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metal catheter: Using a metal catheter is an outdated approach and is not recommended for managing long urethral strictures due to its potential to cause trauma and worsening of the stricture.

 

Option B. Dilation: Dilation is a temporary and often less effective method for managing urethral strictures, especially long ones. It involves stretching the stricture but does not offer a long-term solution and has a high recurrence rate.

 

Option C. Endoscopic urethrotomy: Endoscopic urethrotomy, also known as visual internal urethrotomy, is typically reserved for short segment strictures (less than 1 cm). It involves using a scope to cut the stricture internally. It is not suitable for long segment strictures as it has a higher recurrence rate and limited success in longer strictures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long urethral strictures require reconstructive surgery with techniques such as urethral repair using a buccal mucosal graft to provide a durable and effective solution for restoring normal urethral function.

questions.text: The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hormone receptor staining

 

Hormone receptor status, which determines if the tumor cells have receptors for hormones like estrogen and progesterone, is not included in the VNPI. While hormone receptor status is crucial for managing invasive breast cancers, as it determines potential responses to hormone therapies like tamoxifen, it's not a component of the Van Nuys grading system for DCIS.

 

Staining for estrogen and progesterone receptors is not part of the Van Nuys system used for grading DCIS.

 

The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a grading system that helps to stratify patients with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) based on several factors to determine the likelihood of recurrence and guide treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age of the patient: The age of the patient is one of the factors in the Van Nuys Prognostic Index. Younger age (below 40) is associated with a higher risk of recurrence.

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Tumor size is an essential factor in the Van Nuys grading system. Larger DCIS lesions (> 4cm) are associated with a higher risk of recurrence. Thus, the size can influence the treatment approach.

 

Option D. Presence of necrosis: In DCIS, the presence or absence of necrosis plays a role in determining the prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include Hormone receptor staining.

questions.text: A patient suffered burns following which the surgical procedure was done as shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the likely procedure done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiersch skin graft

 

The image shows a meshed graft, which is characteristic of a Thiersch skin graft, also known as a split-thickness skin graft (STSG). This type of graft involves taking a thin layer of skin from a donor site, which includes the epidermis and part of the dermis. The meshing process creates perforations in the graft, increasing its surface area and allowing exudates to escape, which facilitates healing. Meshing also helps the graft to cover a larger area, which is particularly useful in cases of extensive burns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Full thickness skin graft: This involves transplanting the entire thickness of the skin (epidermis and entire dermis). These grafts are typically used for areas requiring better cosmetic outcomes, such as the face, and are not usually meshed.

 

Option C. Biological mesh: This is used in various surgical repairs, such as hernias, and involves biological material to reinforce or replace tissue. It is not typically used for skin grafting in burns.

 

Option D. Artificial membrane: This refers to synthetic or biologically engineered membranes used to cover wounds or burns. The image shows a skin graft rather than an artificial membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A meshed appearance on a graft used for burn treatment indicates a Thiersch skin graft (split-thickness skin graft), which is designed to cover a larger area and facilitate exudate drainage.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and discomfort for the past few months. The patient also reported experiencing weight loss and loss of appetite. On evaluation, a mass is palpable in the upper abdomen, and an endoscopy shows an ulcerated lesion in the stomach. A biopsy of the lesion is taken and sent for immunohistochemistry. The biopsy sample is found to be positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. Based on these findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GIST

 

The clinical presentation and the biopsy results suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST). GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, and it typically arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or the pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria. GISTs are often associated with symptoms of mass effect, such as abdominal pain and discomfort, and can lead to weight loss and loss of appetite. The diagnosis of GIST is confirmed by immunohistochemistry, which typically shows positivity for KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells. Other immunohistochemical markers such as LCA, cytokeratin, and S100 are negative. Treatment options for GIST may include surgery, radiation therapy, or targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a common type of cancer that can occur in various organs, including the stomach. However, the immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100) are not characteristic of adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Hodgkinâ€™s lymphoma: Hodgkin's lymphoma is a type of lymphoma that typically presents with enlarged lymph nodes and is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question are not consistent with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is commonly associated with the epithelial lining of organs, and its diagnosis would typically involve positive staining for cytokeratin. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (negative for cytokeratin) do not support the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GISTs are mesenchymal tumors that typically occur in the gastrointestinal tract. They often express CD117 (c-kit), a marker commonly associated with GIST. The negative staining for LCA (Leukocyte Common Antigen), cytokeratin, and S100 helps rule out other possibilities and supports the diagnosis of GIST.

questions.text: A patient is found to have a solitary thyroid nodule. What is the first step in his management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Thyroid profile/TSH

 

The initial evaluation of a solitary thyroid nodule begins with a thyroid profile, specifically measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. This is the first step because the TSH test helps determine whether the nodule is functioning (producing thyroid hormone) or non-functioning. If TSH is suppressed, indicating a hyperfunctioning (autonomous) nodule, further evaluation with a radionuclide scan may be appropriate to assess whether the nodule is "hot" (functioning). If TSH is normal or elevated, the next steps typically include an ultrasound (USG) of the neck and possibly fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy, depending on ultrasound findings. The management plan is tailored based on these initial results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radioiodine with I123: This diagnostic scan is typically used after initial thyroid function tests suggest a hyperfunctioning nodule. It is not the first step.

 

Option C. Radioiodine with I131: I131 is primarily used for therapeutic purposes, such as treating hyperthyroidism or certain types of thyroid cancer, not for initial diagnostic evaluation of a thyroid nodule.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): CECT is not routinely used as the first step in the evaluation of thyroid nodules due to its limited ability to characterize thyroid nodules compared to ultrasound and potential interference with subsequent radioactive iodine therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of a solitary thyroid nodule is to assess thyroid function with a TSH test. This guides further diagnostic and management strategies based on whether the nodule is functioning or not.

questions.text: A lady presented to OPD with complaint of pain in the breast. On clinical examination cracks in the nipple were present and fluctuation was positive. Most likely diagnosis in this lady will be? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Breast abscess

 

The patient presents with breast pain, cracked nipples, and a positive fluctuation test. These clinical features are highly suggestive of a breast abscess.

 

  • Cracked nipples: This is a common issue during breastfeeding, leading to an entry point for bacteria. This condition is a significant risk factor for developing infections such as mastitis and abscesses.
  • Fluctuation test positive: This indicates the presence of a fluid-filled cavity, which is characteristic of an abscess.

 

A breast abscess is a localized collection of pus within the breast tissue, usually a complication of mastitis. It presents with a painful, swollen lump in the breast, which may be associated with systemic signs of infection such as fever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Breast engorgement: This condition involves the painful overfilling of the breasts with milk. It is typically seen in breastfeeding women but does not present with cracked nipples or a positive fluctuation test.

 

Option C. Acute Mastitis: While acute mastitis also presents with breast pain and may occur with cracked nipples, the key distinguishing feature here is the positive fluctuation test, which suggests an abscess rather than simple mastitis. Mastitis without abscess formation usually presents with diffuse redness, swelling, and tenderness without fluctuation.

 

Option D. Atypical hyperplasia: This is a precancerous condition involving abnormal cells in the breast but does not present acutely with pain, cracked nipples, or signs of infection such as a positive fluctuation test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a breastfeeding woman with breast pain, cracked nipples, and a positive fluctuation test, the most likely diagnosis is a breast abscess. This condition is a complication of mastitis and requires appropriate management to prevent further complications.

questions.text: Based on the symptoms reported by the patient, what could be the possible diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has been experiencing recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for the past four years? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fistula in ano

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract or channel that develops between the anal canal and the skin around the anus.
  • It is usually caused by an infected anal gland or abscess that fails to heal.
  • The symptoms of a fistula in ano may include pain, swelling, discharge of pus or blood, and recurrent abscesses around the anus.
  • Diagnosis of a fistula in ano is typically made by a physical examination and medical history review.
  • Imaging studies such as MRI or ultrasound may also be used to determine the extent and location of the fistula.
  • Given the patient's chronic history of recurrent discharge and pain around the anus for four years, a fistula in ano is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilonidal sinus: A pilonidal sinus is a small cyst or abscess that occurs in the cleft at the top of the natal cleft. It often contains hair and skin debris. Common symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the area of the buttocks crease, and sometimes it can release pus. Given that the patient's symptoms are around the anus and involve recurrent discharge and pain for several years, a pilonidal sinus, which primarily occurs in the cleft of the buttocks, is less likely.

 

Option B. Carbuncle: A carbuncle is an infective gangrene seen on the back or chest wall. Carbuncles can lead to the formation of an abscess, and symptoms might include a lump filled with pus, which might weep or ooze. While carbuncles can form on any part of the body, their acute and more widespread nature differs from the chronic, recurrent discharge around the anus described by the patient.

 

Option C. Boil: A boil, or furuncle, is a skin infection that starts in a hair follicle or oil gland. It typically starts as a reddened and tender area, which becomes hard and then softens as it fills with pus. Boils can occur anywhere on the body, but they're more common on the face, neck, armpits, buttocks, and thighs. Again, given the chronic and recurrent nature of the patient's symptoms specifically around the anus, a singular boil wouldn't match this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess.
  • The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.

questions.text: In which condition is Grey Turner's sign, characterized by bruising on the abdominal wall, typically observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pancreatitis with hemorrhage

 

The image provided shows the Grey Turner's sign, which is characterized by bruising on the flank area seen in pancreatitis with hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Portal hypertension: There is no connection between Grey Turner's sign and portal hypertension, making this option incorrect.

 

Option C. Cancer stomach: There is no connection between Grey Turner's sign and stomach cancer, rendering this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Pancreatic cancer: Grey Turner's sign is seen in hemorrhagic pancreatitis, not pancreatic cancer, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grey Turner's sign, characterized by bruising on the abdominal wall (flank area), is a clinical manifestation typically observed in cases of hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

questions.text: Arrange the stages of wound healing in the correct sequence: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, remodeling 

 

Wound healing is a complex and dynamic process involving a sequence of interrelated phases. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The correct sequence of wound healing stages is hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling, reflecting the orderly process of wound repair from clot formation to tissue regeneration and maturation.

questions.text: What TNM stage is appropriate for a woman with a breast lump and peau d'orange appearance affecting more than two-thirds of the breast?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T4d

 

Peau d'orange (orange peel appearance) is a clinical sign indicating skin involvement in breast cancer. The TNM staging system for breast cancer classifies tumors with peau d'orange under T4b. However, when the peau d'orange affects a significant portion of the breast, specifically more than one-third of the breast skin, it indicates a more advanced stage known as inflammatory breast carcinoma, which is classified as T4d.

 

Given the information that the peau d'orange affects more than two-thirds of the breast, the appropriate TNM stage is T4d, signifying inflammatory breast carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T4a: This is incorrect as T4a refers to the extension of the tumor to the chest wall.

 

Option B. T4b: This is incorrect as T4b includes peau d'orange but only when it involves less than one-third of the breast skin.

 

Option C. T4c: This is incorrect as T4c is a combination of T4a and T4b, indicating extension to the chest wall and skin involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peau d'orange affecting more than one-third of the breast skin is classified as T4d, indicating inflammatory breast carcinoma.

choices.text: The extent does not cross the wound margins
Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.text: A patient visits the clinic and presents with a raised and firm scar on their chest, which is larger than the original wound. The physician suspects a keloid scar and begins to explain the diagnosis and potential treatment options. Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

 

A keloid scar forms due to an increase in the level of growth factors: This statement is true. Keloid scars are thought to develop due to an overproduction of growth factors, such as transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta), which stimulate the production of collagen and other extracellular matrix components. This abnormal healing response results in the excessive growth of scar tissue beyond the original wound margin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The extent does not cross the wound margins: This statement is not true. Keloid scars are characterized by an excessive growth of fibrous tissue beyond the original wound margin. They tend to be larger, more raised, and thicker than the original wound.

 

Option B. Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence: This statement is also not entirely true. While surgical removal of keloid scars can be effective, the risk of recurrence is high, and the scar may actually grow larger than the original one.

 

Option C. Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity: This statement is not true. Keloid scars are characterized by an overproduction of collagen, which leads to the thick and raised appearance of the scar. There may also be increased vascularity within the scar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloid scars are caused by an overproduction of growth factors like TGF-Î², leading to excessive collagen formation and scar tissue that extends beyond the wound margins.

questions.text: Multiple cutaneous sebaceous adenomas are seen in: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Muir-Torre syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Muir-Torre syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the presence of multiple sebaceous neoplasms, such as sebaceous adenomas, sebaceous carcinomas, and keratoacanthomas, in association with internal malignancies, most commonly colorectal and genitourinary cancers. The identification of multiple sebaceous adenomas should prompt clinicians to evaluate for Muir-Torre syndrome, as these cutaneous lesions are otherwise rare and highly suggestive of this syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gardnerâ€™s syndrome: Incorrect. Gardnerâ€™s syndrome is characterized by multiple colorectal polyps, osteomas, epidermoid cysts, and desmoid tumors, but not typically sebaceous adenomas.

 

Option B. Turcotâ€™s syndrome: Incorrect. Turcotâ€™s syndrome is associated with colorectal polyps and primary brain tumors, such as medulloblastomas and gliomas, but not sebaceous adenomas.

 

Option D. Cowden syndrome: Incorrect. Cowden syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomas and an increased risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers, but sebaceous adenomas are not a common feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple sebaceous adenomas are a hallmark of Muir-Torre syndrome, indicating a potential association with internal malignancies.

questions.text: An inguinal hernia with acute appendicitis occurring in the sac is known as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Amyandâ€™s Hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically defined as an inguinal hernia where the content is the appendix. When the appendix becomes inflamed within the hernia sac, it represents a case of acute appendicitis occurring within an Amyand's hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Richter's Hernia: This occurs when only part of the bowel wall circumference is the content of the hernia. It typically doesn't present with intestinal obstruction but can directly progress to strangulation.
  • Option B. Littre's Hernia: This is defined as a hernia where the content is Meckel's diverticulum, not the appendix.
  • Option D. Maydl's Hernia: This refers to a double loop of intestine within the hernia sac.

 

Named Hernias at a glance:

  1. Omentocele - Content is omentum
  2. Enterocele - Content is intestine
  3. Richter's - Part of bowel wall circumference is in the sac
  4. Littre's - Content is Meckel's diverticulum
  5. Maydl's - Double loop of intestine
  6. Amyand's - Content is appendix
  7. Sliding hernia - Organs like cecum (right) or sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and form a part of the wall of the sac

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically an inguinal hernia containing the appendix, regardless of whether the appendix is inflamed or normal.

questions.text: A young male presented with slight dragging sensation in the scrotum. On examination a bag of worm feel was noted in the left side of scrotum. However, testes were normal. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left varicocele

 

A left varicocele is an enlargement of the veins within the loose bag of skin that holds the testicles (scrotum). It feels like a "bag of worms" and is often described as such during clinical examinations. It's typically benign and more commonly found on the left side. On standing, these veins fill up, leading to the characteristic feeling. The condition can cause a slight dragging sensation in the scrotum but does not affect the testes themselves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left hydrocele: A hydrocele is a fluid-filled sac surrounding a testicle that causes swelling in the scrotum. The fluid collection can be felt as a fluctuant mass in the scrotum. It doesn't give a "bag of worms" feel but more of a smooth swelling.

 

Option B. Inguinal hernia: This condition occurs when tissue, like part of the intestine, protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal muscles. This protrusion can descend into the scrotum, leading to a noticeable bulge. Although it may cause a dragging sensation, the feel on examination would be different from the described "bag of worms".

 

Option C. Epididymo-orchiditis: This is inflammation of the testicle and epididymis, often due to an infection. It typically presents with pain, swelling, and redness of the affected testicle. On examination, the testis and epididymis would be tender and enlarged, but it wouldn't feel like a "bag of worms".

 

Educational Objective:

 

A varicocele is characterized by a "bag of worms" feel in the scrotum and is often found on the left side, causing a slight dragging sensation without affecting the testes.

questions.text: Identify the edges of the lesion given in the following image: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rolled out and beaded

 

The image depicts a skin lesion with particular features at the edges, likely a basal cell carcinoma on face. 

 

This description fits basal cell carcinoma, where the edges of the lesion often have a rolled, pearly appearance due to the nature of tumor growth beneath the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Everted: Everted edges are turned outward or upward. This can be seen in Squamous cell Ca.

 

Option C. Sloping: Sloping edges gradually incline or decline from the lesion to the surrounding skin, without a distinct border. This can be seen in various skin conditions like healing ulcers but is not typically used to describe basal cell carcinoma.

 

Option D. Punched out: Punched-out edges are very steep, almost as if the tissue has been cut with a sharp object. This is more characteristic of trophic or ischemic ulcers. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When identifying skin lesions, rolled out and beaded edges are characteristic of basal cell carcinoma, a common type of skin cancer often seen in sun-exposed areas of the skin.

questions.text: Identify the type of ulcer. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trophic ulcer

 

The image shows an ulcer on the sole of the foot with a characteristic appearance. It is surrounded by a white area due to callosities, indicating chronic pressure. This description is typical of a trophic ulcer, also known as a neuropathic ulcer. These ulcers occur in areas of the body subjected to prolonged pressure, often in patients with peripheral neuropathy. The lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and subsequent ulceration, which is commonly seen in the weight-bearing areas such as the soles of the feet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial ulcer: Arterial ulcers are typically located on the distal parts of the body such as the tips of toes and feet. They are often painful, with a "punched-out" appearance and a well-defined border. They usually have minimal exudate and occur due to inadequate blood supply.

 

Option B. Venous ulcer: Venous ulcers generally occur on the lower legs, particularly around the medial malleolus. They have irregular borders, are usually surrounded by hyperpigmentation, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. These ulcers are often exudative and less painful compared to arterial ulcers.

 

Option D. Diabetic ulcer: While diabetic ulcers can have a neuropathic component, they are a more complex condition with additional ischemic and infectious components. They are not exclusively located on pressure points and can appear anywhere on the foot. The distinguishing factor for trophic ulcers is their location on weight-bearing areas with surrounding callosities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trophic (neuropathic) ulcers typically occur in weight-bearing areas, such as the soles of the feet, and are surrounded by callosities. They are primarily seen in patients with peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and ulceration. Recognizing this type of ulcer is crucial for appropriate management and prevention of further complications.

choices.text: It is done as a life-saving measure
It is done so as to enable the patient to use adequate prosthesis for walking
It is done for emotional care and support
It is done for good functionality

questions.text: A person fell from the train and injured his both legs a few years back. The amputation was done as shown in the image. What is the most likely reason for doing such an amputation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is done as a life-saving measure

 

In cases of severe traumatic injury, such as a person falling from a train and suffering significant leg injuries, amputation is often performed as a life-saving measure. When a limb is crushed, it can lead to a crush syndrome, where the release of myoglobin and potassium from the damaged muscles into the bloodstream can cause acute tubular necrosis of the kidneys and hyperkalemia, leading to fatal arrhythmias. To prevent these life-threatening complications, immediate amputation of the crushed limb is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is done so as to enable the patient to use adequate prosthesis for walking: While amputations are sometimes performed with prosthetic use in mind, this is not the primary consideration in emergency situations involving severe trauma.

 

Option C. It is done for emotional care and support: Amputation is not performed for emotional care; it is a surgical intervention aimed at addressing severe physical injuries.

 

Option D. It is done for good functionality: Functionality considerations, such as optimizing the stump for prosthetic fitting, are secondary to the immediate need to save the patientâ€™s life in cases of severe trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of severe limb trauma, such as a crush injury, amputation is primarily performed as a life-saving measure to prevent complications like crush syndrome and its associated risks.

questions.text: Delphian lymph nodes belong to which level in neck nodes? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Level 6

 

The Delphian lymph node is a prelaryngeal lymph node located just above the thyroid isthmus. In the classification of neck lymph nodes, it is part of:

 

Also known as the central compartment, Level 6 includes the pretracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal (Delphian) lymph nodes. This is the correct level for the Delphian lymph node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levels 3-4: These typically refer to the middle and lower jugular lymph nodes, which are located along the mid and lower third of the internal jugular vein.

 

Option B. Levels 1-2: Level 1 includes the submental and submandibular nodes, and Level 2 includes the upper jugular lymph nodes. These are not the locations of the Delphian lymph node.

 

Option C. Level 5: This includes the posterior triangle group of lymph nodes, located along the lower half of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, extending into the supraclavicular fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Delphian lymph node is categorized as Level 6 in the classification of neck lymph nodes, situated in the central compartment above the thyroid isthmus.

questions.text: Which biopsy technique is used to diagnose Marjolin ulcer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wedge biopsy

 

Wedge biopsy involves the removal of a small, wedge-shaped piece of tissue from the border of an ulcer. This technique is particularly useful in diagnosing Marjolin ulcers because it is the site where squamous cell carcinomas have maximum proliferation, leading to â€œeverted edgeâ€. Marjolin ulcers often develop in areas of previously injured or scarred skin, and a wedge biopsy can provide a representative sample for histopathological examination to confirm the presence of malignancy.


Other Options:

 

Option B. Excision biopsy: Excision biopsy is the technique of choice for a cervical lymph node pathology, in which the entire lymph node is surgically removed for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Core needle biopsy: Core needle biopsy is preferred for sampling soft tissue sarcomas, in which a small sample of tissue is removed using a large bore needle for examination.

 

Option D. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC): USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the technique of choice for a solitary thyroid nodule, in which a small amount of thyroid tissue is aspirated using a thin needle and examined under a microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wedge biopsy is the preferred and commonly used biopsy technique to diagnose Marjolin ulcers because it allows for the examination of tissue from the ulceration site.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents in surgery OPD with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroglossal cyst

 

  • Pathology â€“ Remnant of thyroglossal duct
  • Most common site â€“ midline Ã  Subhyoid
  • C/F â€“ Presents in 2nd /3rd decade of life as midline neck swelling which moves up on tongue protrusion and on deglutition.
  • Treatment - Sistrunkâ€™s operation
  • Long standing thyroglossal cyst has a risk of papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Failure of obliteration of branchial cleft. Cystic swelling (soft)- typically in a teenager. Swelling at upper 1/3rd + middle 1/3rd junction of sternocleidomastoid.

 

 

Option C. Plunging ranula: Presents as Swelling in floor of mouth, Fluctuation present, Brilliant transillumination.

 

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Caused when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue is characteristic of a thyroglossal cyst, which is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • The treatment is typically surgical removal via the Sistrunk procedure.

questions.text: Which patient category is classified as "green" according to the triage system? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ambulatory patients

 

  • The triage system is a method used by medical professionals to prioritize patient care based on the severity of their condition.
  • The triage system typically uses a color-coding scheme to classify patients into different categories.
  • These categories help in quickly identifying which patients need immediate attention and which can wait.
  • Green category: Patients classified under the "green" category are those with non-urgent medical needs. These patients are ambulatory, meaning they can walk and move around on their own. Their injuries or illnesses are minor and do not require immediate medical intervention. These patients can safely wait for medical attention without any significant risk to their health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medium risk patients: Patients classified as medium risk typically fall under the "yellow" category in the triage system. These patients have urgent medical needs but their condition is not immediately life-threatening. They need medical attention soon but can wait for a short period without significant risk to their health.

 

Option C. High risk patients: High risk patients are usually classified under the "red" category. These patients need immediate life-saving interventions due to critical conditions such as severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, or major trauma. Delaying treatment for these patients could result in severe complications or death.

 

Option D. Dead patients: Patients classified as dead or who have injuries that are beyond medical intervention fall under the "black" category. These patients are either deceased or have injuries that are so severe that survival is not expected even with medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "green" category in the triage system is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries or illnesses.
  • These patients do not require immediate medical attention and can safely wait for treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of revised trauma score (RTS)?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pulse rate

 

Pulse rate is NOT a part of revised trauma score.

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a scoring system used to evaluate the severity of traumatic injuries in patients.

 

It takes into account the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate to calculate a score that can predict the likelihood of survival.

 

The score range is 0-12.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glasgow Coma Scale: The GCS is included in the RTS and evaluates the patient's level of consciousness based on eye, verbal, and motor responses.

 

Option B. Systolic Blood Pressure: SBP is included in the RTS and measures the pressure in the arteries when the heart beats.

 

Option D. Respiratory Rate: RR is included in the RTS and measures the number of breaths per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes the Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate, but does not include pulse rate.

questions.text: What is the optimum pressure for VAC? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 100 to 130 mm of Hg

 

Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy, also known as negative pressure wound therapy, is used to promote wound healing by applying controlled negative pressure to the wound area. The optimum pressure for VAC therapy is typically around -125 mm Hg, but a commonly acceptable range is 100 to 130 mm Hg. This pressure range helps to remove exudate, reduce edema, promote granulation tissue formation, and increase local blood flow, thereby enhancing the wound healing process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 70 to 100 mm of Hg: This pressure range is lower than the optimum and may not be as effective in promoting wound healing, as it may not provide sufficient negative pressure to achieve the desired therapeutic effects.

 

Option C. 30 to 50 mm of Hg: This range is far too low to be effective for VAC therapy and would not provide the necessary suction to enhance wound healing.

 

Option D. 10 to 30 mm of Hg: This is significantly below the recommended pressure range and would not contribute effectively to wound management using VAC therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The optimum pressure for Vacuum-Assisted Closure therapy is between 100 to 130 mm Hg, with -125 mm Hg being the most commonly used setting to promote effective wound healing.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Penectomy with inguinal dissection

 

The correct answer is Penectomy with inguinal dissection. The provided images show a post-operative scenario where the penis has been surgically removed, and a perineal urethrostomy has been created with a catheter in place. Additionally, drains are visible in the upper groin area, which are indicative of bilateral inguinal lymph node dissection. This combination of procedures is typical in the management of penile cancer, where both the primary tumor and regional lymph nodes are addressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Orchidectomy: Orchidectomy, or surgical removal of one or both testicles, is not typically part of the treatment for penile cancer unless testicular involvement is specifically noted, which is not suggested by the images. The presence of inguinal dissection further confirms that this is not just an orchidectomy.

 

Option C. Debridement: Debridement is a procedure involving the removal of necrotic or infected tissue to promote wound healing. The images do not show the characteristics of a debridement procedure, such as wound cleansing or preparation for further wound care. Instead, the structured surgical approach seen suggests a more extensive oncologic procedure.

 

Option D. Penectomy with orchidectomy: This is combined procedure is not commonly done, and doesnâ€™t depict the images provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penectomy with inguinal dissection is a treatment approach for penile cancer, involving removal of the penis and associated lymph node dissection to manage local and regional disease spread.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell from a motorbike and injured his perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of the urethra, and swelling of the penis and scrotum was seen. What is the site of injury? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulbar urethra injury

 

  • Clinical Features: Swelling and bruising in the perineal area; difficulty passing urine; blood at the urethral meatus.
  • Treatment Plan: Surgical repair, which may involve primary anastomosis or placement of a suprapubic catheter, depending on the extent of the injury.

 

The presentation of being unable to urinate (urinary retention), the presence of blood at the urethral meatus (hematuria), and the swelling of the penis and scrotum are all indicative of a urethral injury, most likely at the bulbar segment given the described mechanism of injury.

 

The bulbar urethra is the most common site of injury in cases of straddle injuries or perineal trauma, such as the one described in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Membranous Urethra Rupture:

  • Clinical Features: inability to pass urine; blood at the urethral meatus, suprapubic bulge, floating prostate (Vermooten sign).
  • Treatment Plan: Suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Option C. Prostatic Urethra Injury:

  • Similar to membranous urethral rupture.

 

Option D. Urinary Bladder Rupture:

  • Clinical Features: Severe lower abdominal pain, distention, inability to pass urine, signs of shock (hypotension, rapid pulse). No blood is seen at urethral meatus.
  • Treatment Plan: Immediate surgical repair to close the bladder rupture, followed by drainage of urine, and addressing any associated injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulbar urethra injury is a common site of urethral trauma, particularly in cases of straddle injuries or perineal trauma. The key clinical features include difficulty in urination, blood at the urethral meatus, and swelling of the penis and scrotum. The treatment often involves surgical repair or placement of a suprapubic catheter.

choices.text: Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a â€œsure signâ€ of wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serosanguinous drainage from the wound

 

Wound dehiscence is the partial or total separation of layers of a surgical wound. Various signs can indicate this complication, particularly in a post-operative patient who is hypotensive:

 

This type of drainage, which is composed of both blood and serous fluid, can indicate that the wound layers are not properly adhered and may be a sign of impending or actual dehiscence. It's considered a "sure sign" because it often precedes the wound actually coming apart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased bowel sounds: While changes in bowel sounds can be associated with various abdominal conditions like intestinal obstruction, they are not a specific sign of wound dehiscence.

 

Option B. Persistent abdominal pain: Pain is a nonspecific symptom that can be associated with many post-operative complications, including wound dehiscence, but on its own is not a definitive sign.

 

Option D. Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges: While this can occur with wound dehiscence, it is more of a late sign when the wound has already dehisced significantly.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Serosanguinous drainage from the surgical wound is a "sure sign" of wound dehiscence and warrants immediate medical evaluation to prevent further complications.

questions.text: How does this graft get nutrition on day 3? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Inosculation

 

In the process of skin graft healing, the nutrition of the graft changes over time:

 

  1. Imbibition (Days 1-2): During the first two days after the graft is placed, it receives nutrition through plasmatic imbibition. This process involves the absorption of nutrients from the wound bed by diffusion into the graft.
  2. Inosculation (Days 3-5): By the third day, inosculation occurs, which involves the connection of blood vessels from the recipient bed to the blood vessels within the graft. This is a crucial step where initial vascular connections start to form between the graft and the recipient site, providing direct blood flow to the graft.
  3. Neovascularisation (After Day 5): After the fifth day, new blood vessels begin to grow into the graft from the recipient bed, a process known as neovascularization. This ensures that the graft has a stable blood supply, enhancing its long-term survival.
  4. Vascular Anastomosis: This term refers to the surgical connection of blood vessels, which is not typically a mechanism involved in the natural healing of skin grafts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imbibition: This occurs primarily in the first two days post-grafting, where the graft absorbs nutrients by diffusion but not through vascular connections.

 

Option C. Neovascularisation: This process begins after the fifth day, contributing to the long-term survival of the graft through the growth of new blood vessels.

 

Option D. Vascular anastomosis: This is not a natural stage of graft healing but refers to the surgical joining of vessels, which is unrelated to the described natural healing stages of grafts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On day 3, a skin graft receives nutrition primarily through inosculation, where early vascular connections form between the graft and the recipient bed, allowing for initial blood supply to the graft.

questions.text: Identify the most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subhepatic space

 

  1. The right subhepatic space is a deep space located in Rutherford Morison's pouch between the liver, transverse colon, and hepatic flexure. It is a common site of intra-abdominal abscess (second to pelvis).
  2. Abscesses in the right subhepatic space may occur due to conditions such as appendicitis, cholecystitis, perforated duodenal ulcer, or as a complication of upper abdominal surgery.
    • Also known as Rutherford Morison's pouch, the subhepatic space is situated between the liver's posterior surface and the right kidney's anterior surface.
    • It's a potential space that can collect fluid or pus.
    • It is a common site for abscess formation, especially after conditions like appendicitis, where the infection can spread upwards into this space.
    • Due to its anatomical location and the potential for infections like appendicitis to spread to this region, the subhepatic space is recognized as the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peri splenic space: The peri-splenic space is located around the spleen and is bounded by the diaphragm, stomach, and the splenic flexure of the colon. Abscesses in this space can arise from a splenic infection or trauma, but it is not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Option B. Left subphrenic space: The left subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the spleen/stomach. It's a potential space for abscess formation, especially after splenic surgeries or gastric surgeries. However, it's not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses compared to the right side.

 

Option C. Right subphrenic space: The right subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the liver. Abscesses in this space can arise due to infections that spread from the liver or gallbladder, or after surgeries involving these organs. It is one of the potential sites for abscess formation, but not the most common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess is subhepatic space.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after suffering a stab injury to the lower chest. On presentation, he had bradycardia and hypotension which did not improve despite IV fluid administration. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E-FAST
